Adaptive Federated Learning
with Auto-Tuned Clients

Junhyung Lyle Kimâ‹†Â Â Â Mohammad Taha Toghaniâ€ Â Â Â CÃ©sar A.Uribeâ€ Â Â Â Anastasios Kyrillidisâ‹†
â‹†Department of Computer ScienceÂ Â Â â€ Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering
Rice University
Abstract

Federated learning (FL) is a distributed machine learning framework where the global model of a central server is trained via multiple collaborative steps by participating clients without sharing their data. While being a flexible framework, where the distribution of local data, participation rate, and computing power of each client can greatly vary, such flexibility gives rise to many new challenges, especially in the hyperparameter tuning on the client side. We propose Î”Î”\Delta-SGD, a simple step size rule for SGD that enables each client to use its own step size by adapting to the local smoothness of the function each client is optimizing. We provide theoretical and empirical results where the benefit of the client adaptivity is shown in various FL scenarios. 111This work extends Kim etÂ al. (2023) presented at the ICML 2023 Federated Learning Workshop.

1 Introduction

Federated Learning (FL) is a machine learning framework that enables multiple clients to collaboratively learn a global model in a distributed manner. Each client trains the model on their local data, and then sends only the updated model parameters to a central server for aggregation. Mathematically, FL aims to solve the following optimization problem:

minxâˆˆâ„dâ¡fâ€‹(x):=1mâ€‹âˆ‘i=1mfiâ€‹(x),assignsubscriptğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ‘“ğ‘¥1ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥\min_{x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}f(x):=\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i=1}^{m}f_{i}(x), (1)

where fiâ€‹(x):=ğ”¼zâˆ¼ğ’Ÿiâ€‹[Fiâ€‹(x,z)]assignsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ‘§subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–delimited-[]subscriptğ¹ğ‘–ğ‘¥ğ‘§f_{i}(x):=\mathbb{E}_{z\sim\mathcal{D}_{i}}[F_{i}(x,z)] is the loss function of the iğ‘–i-th client, and mğ‘šm is the number of clients.

A key property of FL its flexibility in how various clients participate in the overall training procedure. The number of clients, their participation rates, and computing power available to each client can vary and change at any time during the training. Additionally, the local data of each client is not shared with others, resulting in better data privacy (McMahan etÂ al., 2017; Agarwal etÂ al., 2018).

While advantageous, such flexibility also introduces a plethora of new challenges, notably: i)i) how the server aggregates the local information coming from each client, and ii)ii) how to make sure each client meaningfully â€œlearnsâ€ using their local data and computing device. The first challenge was partially addressed in Reddi etÂ al. (2021), where adaptive optimization methods such as Adam (Kingma & Ba, 2014) was utilized in the aggregation step. Yet, the second challenge remains largely unaddressed.

Local data of each client is not shared, which intrinsically introduces heterogeneity in terms of the size and the distribution of local datasets. That is, ğ’Ÿisubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–\mathcal{D}_{i} differs for each client iğ‘–i, as well as the number of samples zâˆ¼ğ’Ÿisimilar-toğ‘§subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–z\sim\mathcal{D}_{i}. Consequently, fiâ€‹(x)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥f_{i}(x) can vastly differ from client to client, making the problem in (1) hard to optimize. Moreover, the sheer amount of local updates is far larger than the number of aggregation steps, due to the high communication costâ€”typically 3-4Ã—\times orders of magnitude more expensive than local computationâ€”in distributed settings (Lan etÂ al., 2020).

As a result, extensive fine-tuning of the client optimizers is often required to achieve good performance in FL scenarios. For instance, experimental results of the well-known FedAvg algorithm were obtained after performing a grid-search of typically 11-13 step sizes of the clientsâ€™ SGD (McMahan etÂ al., 2017, Section 3), as SGD (and its variants) are highly sensitive to the step size (Toulis & Airoldi, 2017; Assran & Rabbat, 2020; Kim etÂ al., 2022). Similarly, in Reddi etÂ al. (2021), 6 different client step sizes were grid-searched for different tasks, and not surprisingly, each task requires a different client step size to obtain the best result, regardless of the server-side adaptivity (Reddi etÂ al., 2021, Table 8). Importantly, even these â€œfine-tuningsâ€ are done under the setting that all clients use the same step size, which is sub-optimal, given that fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i} can be vastly different per client; we analyze this further in SectionÂ 2.

Initial examination as motivation. The implication of not properly tuning the client optimizer is highlighted in FigureÂ 1. We plot the progress of test accuracies for different client optimizers, where, for all the other test cases, we intentionally use the same step size rules that were fine-tuned for the task in FigureÂ 1(A). There, we train a ResNet-18 for CIFAR-10 dataset classification within an FL setting, where the best step sizes were used for all algorithms after grid-search; we defer the experimental details to SectionÂ 4. Hence, all methods perform reasonably well, although Î”Î”\Delta-SGD, our proposed method, achieves noticeably better test accuracy when compared to non-adaptive SGD variants â€“e.g., a 5% difference in final classification accuracy from SGDMâ€“ and comparable final accuracy only with adaptive SGD variants, like Adam and Adagrad.

In FigureÂ 1(B), we train a shallow CNN for MNIST data classification using the same step size rules. MNIST classification is now considered an â€œeasyâ€ task, and therefore SGD with the same constant and decaying step sizes from FigureÂ 1(A) works well. However, with momentum, SGDM exhibits highly oscillating behavior, which results in slow progress and poor final accuracy, especially without decaying the step size. Adaptive optimizers, like Adam and Adagrad, show similar behavior, falling short in achieving good final accuracy, compared to their performance in the case of FigureÂ 1(A).

Similarly, in FigureÂ 1(C), we plot the test accuracy progress for CIFAR-100 classification trained on ResNet-50, again using the same step size rules as before. Contrary to FigureÂ 1(B), SGD with momentum (SGDM) works better than SGD, both with the constant and the decaying step sizes. Adam becomes a â€œgood optimizerâ€ again, but its â€œsibling,â€ Adagrad, performs worse than SGDM. On the contrary, our proposed method, Î”Î”\Delta-SGD, which we introduce in SectionÂ 3, achieves superior performance in all cases without any additional tuning.

The above empirical observations beg answers to important and non-trivial questions in training FL tasks using variants of SGD methods as the client optimizer: Should the momentum be used? Should the step size be decayed? If so, when? Unfortunately, FigureÂ 1 indicates that the answers to these questions highly vary depending on the setting; once the dataset itself or how the dataset is distributed among different clients changes, or once the model architecture changes, the client optimizers have to be properly re-tuned to ensure good performance. Perhaps surprisingly, the same holds for adaptive methods like Adagrad (Duchi etÂ al., 2011) and Adam (Kingma & Ba, 2014).

Our hypothesis and contributions. Our paper takes a stab in this direction: we propose DELTA-SGD (DistributEd LocaliTy Adaptive SGD), a simple adaptive SGD scheme, that can automatically tune its step size based on the available local data. We will refer to our algorithm as Î”Î”\Delta-SGD in the rest of the text. Our contributions can be summarized as follows:

  • â€¢

    We propose Î”Î”\Delta-SGD, which has two implications in FL settings: i)i) each client can use its own step size, and ii)ii) each clientâ€™s step size adapts to the local smoothness of fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i}â€”hence LocaliTy Adaptiveâ€” and can even increase during local iterations. Moreover, due to the simplicity of the proposed step size, Î”Î”\Delta-SGD is agnostic to the loss function and the server optimizer, and thus can be combined with methods that use different loss functions such as FedProx (Li etÂ al., 2020) or MOON (Li etÂ al., 2021), or adaptive server methods such as FedAdam (Reddi etÂ al., 2021).

  • â€¢

    We provide convergence analysis of Î”Î”\Delta-SGD in a general nonconvex setting (TheoremÂ 1). We also provide the convergence analysis in the convex setting, as well as a simple centralized nonconvex convergence analysis. Due to space constraints, we only state the result of general nonconvex case in TheoremÂ 1, and defer other theorems and proofs to AppendixÂ A.

  • â€¢

    We evaluate our approach on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate that Î”Î”\Delta-SGD achieves superior performance compared to other state-of-the-art FL methods. Our experiments show that Î”Î”\Delta-SGD can effectively adapt the client step size to the underlying local data distribution, and achieve convergence of the global model without any additional tuning. Our approach can help overcome the client step size tuning challenge in FL and enable more efficient and effective collaborative learning in distributed systems.

2 Preliminaries and Related Work

A bit of background on optimization theory. Arguably the most fundamental optimization algorithm for minimizing a function fâ€‹(x):â„dâ†’â„:ğ‘“ğ‘¥â†’superscriptâ„ğ‘‘â„f(x):\mathbb{R}^{d}\rightarrow\mathbb{R} is the gradient descent (GD) (Cauchy etÂ al., 1847), which iterates with the step size Î·tsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡\eta_{t} as: xt+1=xtâˆ’Î·tâ€‹âˆ‡fâ€‹(xt)subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡âˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡x_{t+1}=x_{t}-\eta_{t}\nabla f(x_{t}). Under the assumption that fğ‘“f is globally Lğ¿L-smooth, that is:

â€–âˆ‡fâ€‹(x)âˆ’âˆ‡fâ€‹(y)â€–â©½Lâ‹…â€–xâˆ’yâ€–âˆ€x,yâˆˆâ„d,formulae-sequencenormâˆ‡ğ‘“ğ‘¥âˆ‡ğ‘“ğ‘¦â‹…ğ¿normğ‘¥ğ‘¦for-allğ‘¥ğ‘¦superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\|\nabla f(x)-\nabla f(y)\|\leqslant L\cdot\|x-y\|\quad\forall x,y\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, (2)

the step size Î·t=1Lsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡1ğ¿\eta_{t}=\frac{1}{L} is the â€œoptimalâ€ step size for GD, which converges for convex fğ‘“f at the rate:

fâ€‹(xt+1)âˆ’fâ€‹(xâ‹†)â©½Lâ€‹â€–x0âˆ’xâ‹†â€–22â€‹(2â€‹t+1).ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡1ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥â‹†ğ¿superscriptnormsubscriptğ‘¥0superscriptğ‘¥â‹†222ğ‘¡1f(x_{t+1})-f(x^{\star})\leqslant\frac{L\|x_{0}-x^{\star}\|^{2}}{2(2t+1)}. (3)

Limitations of popular step sizes. In practice, however, the constants like Lğ¿L are rarely known (Boyd etÂ al., 2004). As such, there has been a plethora of efforts in the optimization community to develop a universal step size rule or method that does not require a priori knowledge of problem constants so that an optimization algorithm can work as â€œplug-and-playâ€ (Nesterov, 2015; Orabona & PÃ¡l, 2016; Levy etÂ al., 2018). A major lines of work on this direction include: i)i) line-search (Armijo, 1966; Paquette & Scheinberg, 2020), ii)ii) adaptive learning rate (e.g., Adagrad (Duchi etÂ al., 2011) and Adam (Kingma & Ba, 2014)), and iii)iii) Polyak step size (Polyak, 1969), to name a few.

Unfortunately, the pursuit of finding the â€œidealâ€ step size is still active (Loizou etÂ al., 2021; Defazio & Mishchenko, 2023; Bernstein etÂ al., 2023; Latafat etÂ al., 2023), as the aforementioned approaches have limitations. For instance, to use line search, solving a sub-routine is required, inevitably incurring additional evaluations of the function and/or the gradient. To use methods like Adagrad and Adam, the knowledge of Dğ·D, the distance from the initial point to the solution set, is required to ensure good performance (Defazio & Mishchenko, 2023). Similarly, Polyak step size requires a sharp knowledge of fâ€‹(xâ‹†)ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥â‹†f(x^{\star}) (Hazan & Kakade, 2019), which is not always known a priori, and is unclear what value to use for an arbitrary loss function and model; see also SectionÂ 4 where not properly estimating Dğ·D or fâ€‹(xâ‹†)ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥â‹†f(x^{\star}) resulting in suboptimal performance of relevant client optimizers in FL scenarios.

Implications in distributed/FL scenarios. The global Lğ¿L-smoothness in (2) needs to be satisfied for all xğ‘¥x and yğ‘¦y, implying even finite Lğ¿L can be arbitrarily large. This results in a small step size, leading to slow convergence, as seen inÂ (3). Malitsky & Mishchenko (2020) attempted to resolve this issue by proposing a step size for GD that depends on the local smoothness of fğ‘“f, which by definition is smaller than the global Lğ¿L from (2). Î”Î”\Delta-SGD is inspired from this work.

Naturally, the challenge is aggravated in the distributed case. To solve (1) under the assumption that each fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i} is Lisubscriptğ¿ğ‘–L_{i}-smooth, the step size of the form 1/Lmax1subscriptğ¿max{1}/{L_{\text{max}}} where Lmax:=maxiâ¡Liassignsubscriptğ¿maxsubscriptğ‘–subscriptğ¿ğ‘–{L_{\text{max}}}:=\max_{i}L_{i} is often used (Yuan etÂ al., 2016; Scaman etÂ al., 2017; Qu & Li, 2019), to ensure convergence (Uribe etÂ al., 2020). Yet, one can easily imagine a situation where Liâ‰«Ljmuch-greater-thansubscriptğ¿ğ‘–subscriptğ¿ğ‘—L_{i}\gg L_{j} for iâ‰ j,ğ‘–ğ‘—i\neq j, in which case the convergence of fjâ€‹(x)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—ğ‘¥f_{j}(x) can be arbitrarily slow by using step size of the form 1/Lmax1subscriptğ¿max{1}/{L_{\text{max}}}.

Therefore, to ensure that each client learns useful information in FL settings as in (1), ideally: i)i) each agent should be able to use its own step size, instead of crude ones like 1/Lmax1subscriptğ¿max1/L_{\text{max}} for all agents; ii)ii) the individual step size should be â€œlocally adaptiveâ€ to the function fi,subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i}, (i.e., even 1/Li1subscriptğ¿ğ‘–1/L_{i} can be too crude, analogously to the centralized GD); and iii)iii) the step size should not depend on problem constants like Lisubscriptğ¿ğ‘–L_{i} an Î¼isubscriptğœ‡ğ‘–\mu_{i}, which are often unknown. In SectionÂ 3, we introduce DistributEd LocaliTy Adaptive SGD (Î”Î”\Delta-SGD), which satisfies all of the aforementioned desiderata.

Related work on FL. The literature of FL algorithms is vast; here, we focus on the results that closely relate to our work. The FedAvg algorithm (McMahan etÂ al., 2017) is one of the simplest FL algorithms, which averages client parameters after some local iterations. Reddi etÂ al. (2021) showed that FedAvg is a special case of a meta-algorithm, where both the clients and the server use the SGD optimizer, with the server learning rate being 1. To handle data heterogeneity and model drift, they proposed using an adaptive optimization scheme at the server. This results in algorithms such as Â FedAdam and FedYogi, which respectively use the Adam (Kingma & Ba, 2014) and Yogi (Zaheer etÂ al., 2018) as server optimizers. Our approach is orthogonal and complimentary, as we propose a client adaptive optimizer that can be easily combined with these server-side aggregation methods.

Other approaches have handled the heterogeneity by changing the loss function. FedProx (Li etÂ al., 2020) adds an â„“2subscriptâ„“2\ell_{2}-norm proximal term to to handle data heterogeneity. Similarly, MOONÂ (Li etÂ al., 2021) uses the model-contrastive loss between the current and previous models. Again, our proposed method can be seamlessly combined with these approaches (c.f., TablesÂ 4(b) and 4).

The closest related work to ours is a concurrent work by Mukherjee etÂ al. (2023). There, authors utilize the Stochastic Polyak Stepsize (Loizou etÂ al., 2021) in FL settings. We do include SPS results in SectionÂ 4. There are some previous works that considered client adaptivity, including AdaAlter (Xie etÂ al., 2019a) and Wang etÂ al. (2021). Both works utilize an adaptive client optimizer, similar to Adagrad. However, AdaAlter incurs twice the memory compared to FedAvg, as AdaAlter requires communicating both the model parameters as well as the â€œclient accumulatorsâ€; similarly, Wang etÂ al. (2021) requires complicated local and global correction steps to achieve good performance. In short, previous works that utilize client adaptivity require modification in server-side aggregation; without such heuristics, Adagrad (Duchi etÂ al., 2011) exhibits suboptimal performance, as seen in TableÂ 1.

Lastly, another line of works attempts to handle heterogeneity by utilizing control-variates (PraneethÂ Karimireddy etÂ al., 2019; Liang etÂ al., 2019; Karimireddy etÂ al., 2020), a similar idea to variance reduction from single-objective optimization (Johnson & Zhang, 2013; Gower etÂ al., 2020). While theoretically appealing, these methods either require periodic full gradient computation or are not usable under partial client participation, as all the clients must maintain a state throughout all rounds.

3.1 Convergence Analysis

Technical challenges. The main difference of analyzing AlgorithmÂ 1 compared to other decentralized optimization theories is that the step size Î·t,kisuperscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğ‘–\eta_{t,k}^{i} not only depends on the round tğ‘¡t and local steps kğ‘˜k, but also on iğ‘–i, the client. To deal with the client-dependent step size, we require a slightly non-standard assumption on the dissimilarity between fğ‘“f and fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i}, as detailed below.

Assumption 1.

There exist nonnegative constants Ïƒ,Ï,ğœğœŒ\sigma,\rho, and GğºG such that for all iâˆˆ[M]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘€i\in[M] and xâˆˆâ„dğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x\in\mathbb{R}^{d},

ğ”¼â€‹â€–âˆ‡Fiâ€‹(x,z)âˆ’âˆ‡fiâ€‹(x)â€–2ğ”¼superscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘–ğ‘¥ğ‘§âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\|\nabla F_{i}(x,z)-\nabla f_{i}(x)\|^{2} â©½Ïƒ2,absentsuperscriptğœ2\displaystyle\leqslant\sigma^{2}, (bounded variance) (1a)
â€–âˆ‡fiâ€‹(x)â€–normâˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥\displaystyle\|\nabla f_{i}(x)\| â©½G,absentğº\displaystyle\leqslant G, (bounded gradient) (1b)
â€–âˆ‡fiâ€‹(x)âˆ’âˆ‡fâ€‹(x)â€–2superscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥âˆ‡ğ‘“ğ‘¥2\displaystyle\|\nabla f_{i}(x)-\nabla f(x)\|^{2} â©½Ïâ€‹â€–âˆ‡fâ€‹(x)â€–2.absentğœŒsuperscriptnormâˆ‡ğ‘“ğ‘¥2\displaystyle\leqslant\rho\|\nabla f(x)\|^{2}. (strong growth of dissimilarity) (1c)

AssumptionÂ 1a has been standard in stochastic optimization literatureÂ (Ghadimi & Lan, 2013; Stich, 2018; Khaled etÂ al., 2020); recently, this assumption has been relaxed to weaker ones such as weak growth assumptionÂ (Bottou etÂ al., 2018) or expected smoothness (Gower etÂ al., 2021), but this is out of scope of this work. AssumptionÂ 1b is fairly standard in nonconvex optimization (Zaheer etÂ al., 2018; Ward etÂ al., 2020), and often used in FL setting (Xie etÂ al., 2019a; b; Reddi etÂ al., 2021). AssumptionÂ 1c is reminiscent of the strong growth assumption in stochastic optimization literature (Schmidt & Roux, 2013), which is still used in recent works (Cevher & VÅ©, 2019; Vaswani etÂ al., 2019a; b). To the best of our knowledge, this is the first theoretical analysis of the FL setting where clients can use their step size. We now present the main convergence theorem of AlgorithmÂ 1.

Theorem 1.

Let Assumption 1 hold, with Ï=ğ’ªâ€‹(1)ğœŒğ’ª1\rho=\mathcal{O}(1). 4 Experimental Setup and Results

Datasets and models. We consider image classification and text classification tasks. We use four datasets for image classification tasks: MNIST, FMNIST, CIFAR-10, and CIFAR-100 (Krizhevsky etÂ al., 2009). For MNIST and FMNIST, we train a shallow CNN with two convolutional and two fully-connected layers, followed by dropout and ReLU activations. For CIFAR-10, we train a ResNet-18 (He etÂ al., 2016). For CIFAR-100, we train both a ResNet-18 and a ResNet-50 to study the effect of changing the model architecture. For the text classification tasks, we use two datasets: DBpedia and AGnews datasets (Zhang etÂ al., 2015), and train a DistillBERT (Sanh etÂ al., 2019) for classification.

For each dataset, we create a federated version by randomly partitioning the training data among 100100100 clients (505050 for text classification), with each client getting 500500500 examples. To control the level of non-iidness, we apply latent Dirichlet allocation (LDA) over the labels following (Hsu etÂ al., 2019), where the degree class heterogeneity can be paramterized by the dirichlet concentration parameter Î±.ğ›¼\alpha. The class distribution of different Î±ğ›¼\alphaâ€™s is visualized in FigureÂ 5 in AppendixÂ B.

FL setup and optimizers. We fix the number of clients to be 100100100 for the image classification, and 505050 for the text classification; we randomly sample 10%percent1010\% as participating clients. We perform Eğ¸E local epochs of training over each clientâ€™s dataset. We utilize mini-batch gradients of size b=64ğ‘64b=64 for the image classification, and b=16ğ‘16b=16 for the text classification, leading to Kâ‰ˆâŒŠEâ‹…500bâŒ‹ğ¾â‹…ğ¸500ğ‘K\approx\lfloor\tfrac{E\cdot 500}{b}\rfloor local gradient steps; we use E=1ğ¸1E=1 for all settings. For client optimizers, we compare stochastic gradient descent (SGD), SGD with momentum (SGDM), adaptive methods including Adam (Kingma & Ba, 2014), Adagrad (Duchi etÂ al., 2011), SGD with stochastic Polyak step size (SPS) (Loizou etÂ al., 2021), and our proposed method: Î”Î”\Delta-SGD in AlgorithmÂ 1. As our focus is on client adaptivity, we only present the results using FedAvg (McMahan etÂ al., 2017) as the server optimizer, similarly to how Reddi etÂ al. (2021) fixes the client optimizer to be plain SGD for all cases.

Hyperparameters. For all methods, we perform a grid search on a single task: CIFAR-10 classification trained with ResNet-18, with Dirichlet concentration parameter Î±=0.1ğ›¼0.1\alpha=0.1; for the rest of the settings, we use the same hyperparameters. For SGD, we perform a grid search with Î·âˆˆ{0.01,0.05,0.1,0.5}ğœ‚0.010.050.10.5\eta\in\{0.01,0.05,0.1,0.5\}. For SGDM, we use the same grid for Î·ğœ‚\eta and use momentum parameter Î²=0.9ğ›½0.9\beta=0.9. For Adam and Adagrad, we grid search with Î·âˆˆ{0.001,0.01,0.1}.ğœ‚0.0010.010.1\eta\in\{0.001,0.01,0.1\}. For SPS, we use the default setting of the official implementation.555I.e., we use fiâ‹†=0superscriptsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–â‹†0f_{i}^{\star}=0, and c=0.5,ğ‘0.5c=0.5, for the SPS step size: fiâ€‹(x)âˆ’fiâ‹†câ€‹â€–âˆ‡fiâ€‹(x)â€–2subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–â‹†ğ‘superscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥2\frac{f_{i}(x)-f_{i}^{\star}}{c\|\nabla f_{i}(x)\|^{2}}. The official implementation can be found in https://github.com/IssamLaradji/sps For Î”Î”\Delta-SGD, we append Î´ğ›¿\delta in front of the second condition: 1+Î´â€‹Î¸t,kâˆ’1iâ€‹Î·t,kâˆ’1i1ğ›¿superscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘¡ğ‘˜1ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡ğ‘˜1ğ‘–\sqrt{1+\delta\theta_{t,k-1}^{i}}\eta_{t,k-1}^{i} following Malitsky & Mishchenko (2020), and use Î´=0.1ğ›¿0.1\delta=0.1 for all experiments666However, as shown in FigureÂ 4 in AppendixÂ B, Î´ğ›¿\delta has very little impact on the final accuracy.. To properly account for the SGD(M) fine-tuning typically done in practice, we also test dividing the step size (LR decay) by 10 after 50%percent5050\%, and then again by 10 after 75%percent7575\% of the total training rounds, and report the inclusive results in TableÂ 1. Finally, for the number of rounds Tğ‘‡T, we use 500500500 for MNIST, 100010001000 for FMNIST, 200020002000 for CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100, and 100100100 for the text classification tasks.

4.1 Results

We clarify here in advance that the best step size for each client optimizer was tuned via grid-search for a single task: CIFAR-10 classification trained with a ResNet-18, with Dirichlet concentration parameter Î±=0.1ğ›¼0.1\alpha=0.1. We then intentionally use the same step size in all other tasks to highlight two points: i)i) Î”Î”\Delta-SGD works well without any tuning across different datasets, model architectures, and degrees of heterogeneity; ii)ii) other optimizers perform suboptimally without additional tuning.

Results of the experiments detailed in the previous subsection are presented in TableÂ 1. Below, we make comprehensive remarks.

Changing the level of non-iidness. We first investigate how the performance of different client optimizers degrade in increasing degrees of heterogeneity by varying the concentration parameter Î±âˆˆ{1,0.1,0.01}ğ›¼10.10.01\alpha\in\{1,0.1,0.01\} multiplied to the prior of Dirichlet distribution, following (Hsu etÂ al., 2019).

Three illustrative cases are visualized in FigureÂ 2. We remind that the step sizes are tuned for the task in FigureÂ 2(A). For this task, with Î±=1ğ›¼1\alpha=1 (i.e., closer to iid), all methods perform better than Î±=0.1,ğ›¼0.1\alpha=0.1, as expected. With Î±=0.01,ğ›¼0.01\alpha=0.01, which is highly non-iid (c.f., FigureÂ 5 in AppendixÂ B), we see a significant drop in performance for all methods. SGD with LR decay and Î”Î”\Delta-SGD perform the best, while adaptive methods like Adam (85%â†’22.1%â†’percent85percent22.185\%\rightarrow 22.1\%) and Adagrad (84.1%â†’12.5%â†’percent84.1percent12.584.1\%\rightarrow 12.5\%) degrade noticeably more than other methods.

FigureÂ 2(B) shows the results of training FMNIST with a CNN. This problem is generally considered easier than CIFAR-10 classification. The experiments show that the performance degradation with varying Î±ğ›¼\alphaâ€™s is much milder in this case. Interestingly, adaptive methods such as Adam, Adagrad, and SPS perform much worse than other methods

Lastly, in FigureÂ 2(C), results for CIFAR-100 classification trained with ResNet-50 are illustrated. Î”Î”\Delta-SGD exhibits superior performance in all cases of Î±ğ›¼\alpha. Unlike MNIST and FMNIST, Adam enjoys the second (Î±=0.1ğ›¼0.1\alpha=0.1) or the third (Î±=1ğ›¼1\alpha=1) best performance in this task, complicating how one should â€œtuneâ€ Adam for the task at hand. Other methods, including SGD with and without momentum/LR decay, Adagrad, and SPS, perform much worse than Î”Î”\Delta-SGD.

Changing the model architecture/dataset. For this remark, let us focus on CIFAR-100 trained on ResNet-18 versus on ResNet-50, with Î±=0.1ğ›¼0.1\alpha=0.1, illustrated in FigureÂ 3(A). SGD and SGDM (both with and without LR decay), Adagrad, and SPS perform worse using ResNet-50 than ResNet-18. This is a counter-intuitive behavior, as one would expect to get better accuracy by using a more powerful model. Î”Î”\Delta-SGD is an exception: without any additional tuning, Î”Î”\Delta-SGD can improve its performance. Adam also improves similarly, but the achieved accuracy is significantly worse than that of Î”Î”\Delta-SGD.

We now focus on cases where the dataset changes, but the model architecture remains the same. We mainly consider two cases, illustrated in FigureÂ 3(B) and (C): When CNN is trained for classifying MNIST versus FMNIST, and when ResNet-18 is trained for CIFAR-10 versus CIFAR-100. From (B), one can infer the difficulty in tuning SGDM: without the LR decay, SGDM only achieves around 78% accuracy for MNIST classification, while SGD without LR decay still achieves over 96%percent9696\% accuracy. For FMNIST on the other hand, SGDM performs relatively well, but adaptive methods like Adam, Adagrad, and SPS degrade significantly.

Aggravating the complexity of fine-tuning SGD(M) for MNIST, one can observe from (C) a similar trend in CIFAR-10 trained with ResNet-18. In that case, Î”Î”\Delta-SGD does not achieve the best test accuracy (although it is the second best with a pretty big margin with the rest), while SGD with LR decay does. However, without LR decay, the accuracy achieved by SGD drops more than 11%. Again, adaptive methods like Adam, Adagrad, and SPS perform suboptimally in this case.

Changing the domain: text classification. In TableÂ 4(a), we make a bigger leap, and test the performance of different client optimizers for text classification tasks. The best step size for each client optimizer is tuned for the CIFAR-10 image classification trained with a ResNet-18, for Î±=0.1ğ›¼0.1\alpha=0.1. Here, the type of the dataset completely changed from image to text, as well as the model architecture: from vision to language.

Not surprisingly, four methods (SGDM, SGDM(â†“â†“\downarrow), Adam, and Adagrad) ended up learning nothing (i.e., the achieved accuracy is 1/(# of labels)), indicating the fine-tuned step size for the CIFAR-10 classification task was too large for the considered text classification tasks. Î”Î”\Delta-SGD, on the other hand, still achieved competitive accuracies without additional tuning, thanks to the locality adaptive step size. Interestingly, SGD, SGD(â†“â†“\downarrow), and SPS worked well for the text classification tasks, which is contrary to their suboptimal performances for image classification in TableÂ 1.

Changing the loss function. In TableÂ 4(b), we illustrate how Î”Î”\Delta-SGD performs when combined with a different loss function, such as FedProx (Li etÂ al., 2020). FedProx aims to enhance heterogeneity, and thus we tested it with the lowest concentration parameter for CIFAR-10 classification with ResNet-18 and CIFAR-100 classification with ResNet-50. The results show that Î”Î”\Delta-SGD again outperforms all other methods with a significant margin: Î”Î”\Delta-SGD is not only the best, but also the performance difference is at least 2.5%, and as large as 26.9%. However, compared to the original setting without the proximal term in TableÂ 1, it is unclear whether or not the additional proximal term helps. For Î”Î”\Delta-SGD, the accuracy increased for CIFAR-10 with ResNet-18, but slightly got worse for CIFAR-100 with ResNet-50; similar story applies to other methods.

Other findings. We present all the omitted theorems and proofs in AppendixÂ A, and additional empirical findings in AppendixÂ B. Specifically, we demonstrate: the robustness of the performance of Î”Î”\Delta-SGD (AppendixÂ B.1), visualization of the degree of heterogeneity (AppendixÂ B.2), the effect of different number of local iterations (AppendixÂ B.3), additional experiments when the size of local dataset are different per client (AppendixÂ B.4), and additional experiential results using MOON (AppendixÂ B.5).

5 Conclusion

In this work, we proposed Î”Î”\Delta-SGD, a distributed SGD scheme equipped with an adaptive step size that enables each client to use its step size and adapts to the local smoothness of the function each client is optimizing. We proved the convergence of Î”Î”\Delta-SGD in the general nonconvex setting and presented extensive empirical results, where the superiority of Î”Î”\Delta-SGD is shown in various scenarios without any tuning. For future works, extending Î”Î”\Delta-SGD to a coordinate-wise step size in the spirit of (Duchi etÂ al., 2011; Kingma & Ba, 2014), as well as enabling asynchronous updates (Assran etÂ al., 2020; Toghani etÂ al., 2022; Nguyen etÂ al., 2022) could be interesting directions.

A.3 Proof of adaptive gradient descent in nonconvex case: centralized

For this part, we use the centralized step size from Malitsky & Mishchenko (2020):

Î·t=minâ¡{â€–xtâˆ’xtâˆ’1â€–2â€‹â€–âˆ‡fâ€‹(xt)âˆ’âˆ‡fâ€‹(xtâˆ’1)â€–,1+Î¸tâˆ’1â€‹Î·tâˆ’1},Î¸tâˆ’1=Î·tâˆ’1/Î·tâˆ’2.formulae-sequencesubscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡normsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡12normâˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡âˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡11subscriptğœƒğ‘¡1subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡1subscriptğœƒğ‘¡1subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡1subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡2\displaystyle\eta_{t}=\min\Big{\{}\tfrac{\|x_{t}-x_{t-1}\|}{2\|\nabla f(x_{t})-\nabla f(x_{t-1})\|},\sqrt{1+\theta_{t-1}}\eta_{t-1}\Big{\}},\quad\theta_{t-1}=\eta_{t-1}/\eta_{t-2}. (44)
Theorem 6.

Appendix B Additional Experiments and Plots

B.1 Ease of tuning

In this subsection, we show the effect of using different parameter Î´ğ›¿\delta in the step size of Î”Î”\Delta-SGD. As mentioned in SectionÂ 4, for Î”Î”\Delta-SGD, we append Î´ğ›¿\delta in front of the second condition, and hence the step size becomes

Î·t,ki=minâ¡{Î³â€‹â€–xt,kiâˆ’xt,kâˆ’1iâ€–2â€‹â€–âˆ‡~â€‹fiâ€‹(xt,ki)âˆ’âˆ‡~â€‹fiâ€‹(xt,kâˆ’1i)â€–,1+Î´â€‹Î¸t,kâˆ’1iâ€‹Î·t,kâˆ’1i}.superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğ‘–ğ›¾normsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘˜1ğ‘–2norm~âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğ‘–~âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘˜1ğ‘–1ğ›¿superscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘¡ğ‘˜1ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡ğ‘˜1ğ‘–\eta_{t,k}^{i}=\min\Big{\{}\tfrac{\gamma\|x_{t,k}^{i}-x_{t,{k-1}}^{i}\|}{2\|\tilde{\nabla}f_{i}(x_{t,k}^{i})-\tilde{\nabla}f_{i}(x_{t,{k-1}}^{i})\|},\sqrt{1+\delta\theta_{t,k-1}^{i}}\eta_{t,k-1}^{i}\Big{\}}.

The experimental results presented in TableÂ 1 were obtained using a value of Î´=0.1ğ›¿0.1\delta=0.1. For Î³ğ›¾\gamma, we remind the readers that we did not change from the default value Î³=2ğ›¾2\gamma=2 in the original implementation in https://github.com/ymalitsky/adaptive_GD/blob/master/pytorch/optimizer.py.

In FigureÂ 4, we display the final accuracy achieved when using different values of Î´ğ›¿\delta from the set {0.01,0.1,1}0.010.11\{0.01,0.1,1\}. Interestingly, we observe that Î´ğ›¿\delta has very little impact on the final accuracy. This suggests that Î”Î”\Delta-SGD is remarkably robust and does not require much tuning, while consistently achieving higher test accuracy compared to other methods in the majority of cases as shown in TableÂ 1.

B.2 Illustration of the degree of non-iidness

As mentioned in the main text, the level of â€œnon-iidnessâ€ is controlled using latent Dirichlet allocation (LDA) applied to the labels. This approach is based on (Hsu etÂ al., 2019) and involves assigning each client a multinomial distribution over the labels. This distribution determines the labels from which the clientâ€™s training examples are drawn. Specifically, the local training examples for each client are sampled from a categorical distribution over Nğ‘N classes, parameterized by a vector ğªğª\mathbf{q}. The vector ğªğª\mathbf{q} is drawn from a Dirichlet distribution with a concentration parameter Î±ğ›¼\alpha times a prior distribution vector ğ©ğ©\mathbf{p} over Nğ‘N classes.

To vary the level of â€œnon-iidness,â€ different values of Î±ğ›¼\alpha are considered: 0.01,0.10.010.10.01,0.1, and 111. A larger Î±ğ›¼\alpha corresponds to settings that are closer to i.i.d. scenarios, while smaller values introduce more diversity and non-iidness among the clients, as visualized in FigureÂ 5. As can be seen, for Î±=1,ğ›¼1\alpha=1, each client (each row on yğ‘¦y-axis) have fairly diverse classes, similarly to the i.i.d. case; as we decrease Î±,ğ›¼\alpha, the number of classes that each client has access to decreases. With Î±=0.01,ğ›¼0.01\alpha=0.01, there are man y clients who only have access to a single or a couple classes.

B.3 Effect of different number of local iterations

In this subsection, we show the effect of different number of local epochs performed per client, while fixing the experimental setup to be the classification of CIFAR-100 datset, trained with a ResNet-50. We show for all three cases of the Dirichlet concentration parameter Î±âˆˆ{0.01,0.1,1}ğ›¼0.010.11\alpha\in\{0.01,0.1,1\}. The result is shown in FigureÂ 6.

As mentioned in the main text, instead of performing local iterations, we instead perform local epochs E,ğ¸E, similarly to (Reddi etÂ al., 2021; Li etÂ al., 2020). All the results in TableÂ 1 use E=1,ğ¸1E=1, and in FigureÂ 6, we show the results for Eâˆˆ{1,2,3}ğ¸123E\in\{1,2,3\}. Note that in terms of Eğ¸E, the considered numbers might be small difference, but in terms of actual local gradient steps, they differ significantly.

As can be seen, using higher Eğ¸E leads to slightly faster convergence in all cases of Î±.ğ›¼\alpha. However, the speed up seems marginal compared to the amount of extra computation time it requires (i.e., using E=2ğ¸2E=2 takes roughly twice more total wall-clock time than using E=1ğ¸1E=1). Put differently, Î”Î”\Delta-SGD performs well with only using a single local epoch per client (E=1ğ¸1E=1), and still can achieve great performance.

B.4 Additional experiments using different number of local data per client

In this subsection, we provide additional experimental results, where the size of the local dataset each client has differs. In particular, instead of distributing 500500500 samples to each client as done in SectionÂ 4 of the main text, we distribute niâˆˆ[100,500]subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–100500n_{i}\in[100,500] samples for each client iğ‘–i, where nisubscriptğ‘›ğ‘–n_{i} is the number of samples that client iğ‘–i has, and is randomly sampled from the range [100,500]100500[100,500]. We keep all other settings the same.

Then, in the server aggregation step (line 13 of AlgorithmÂ 1), we compute the weighted average of the local parameters, instead of the plain average, as suggested in (McMahan etÂ al., 2017), and used for instance in (Reddi etÂ al., 2021).

We experiment in two settings: CIFAR-10 dataset classification trained with a ResNet-18 (He etÂ al., 2016), with Dirichlet concentration parameter Î±=0.1,ğ›¼0.1\alpha=0.1, which was the setting where the algorithms were fined-tuned using grid search; please see details in SectionÂ 4. We also provide results for CIFAR-100 dataset classification trained with a ResNet-50, with the same Î±.ğ›¼\alpha.

The result can be found in TableÂ 3. Similarly to the case with same number of data per client, i.e.,ni=500i.e.,n_{i}=500 for all iâˆˆ[m],ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘ši\in[m], we see that Î”Î”\Delta-SGD achieves good performance without any additional tuning. In particular, for CIFAR-10 classification trained with a ResNet-18, Î”Î”\Delta-SGD achieves the second best performance after SGD (without LR decay), with a small margin. Interestingly, SGDM (both with and without LR decay) perform much worse than SGD. This contrasts with the same setting in TableÂ 1, where SGDM performed better than SGD, which again complicates how one should tune client optimizers in the FL setting. For CIFAR-100 classification trained with ResNet-50, Î”Î”\Delta-SGD outperforms all other methods with large margin.

B.5 Additional experiments using MOON

Here, we provide additional experimental results using MOON (Li etÂ al., 2021), which utilizes model-contrastive learning to handle heterogeneous data. In this sense, the goal of MOON is very similar to that of FedProx (Li etÂ al., 2020); yet, due to the model-contrastive learning nature, it can incur bigger memory overhead compared to FedProx, as one needs to keep track of the previous model(s) to compute the representation of each local batch from the local model of last round, as well as the global model.

As such, we only ran using MOON for CIFAR-10 classification using a ResNet-18; for the CIFAR-100 classification using a ResNet-50, our computing resource ran out of memory to run the same configuration we ran in the main text.

The results are summarized in TableÂ 4. As can be seen, even ignoring the fact that MOON utilizes more memory, MOON does not help for most of the optimizersâ€“it actually often results in worse final accuracies than the corresponding results in TableÂ 1 from the main text.
